details.title: A hierarchy of importance indices

p: F. K. Hwang obtained his B.A. degree from National Taiwan University in 1960, and his Ph.D. in Statistics from North Carolina State University in 1968. He worked at the Mathematics Research Center, Bell Labs from 1967 to 1996, and has been a university chair professor at National Chiaotung University, since 1996. He has published about 350 papers, and written 4 books including “Reliabilities of the Consecutive-$k$ Systems.”

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Appl. Math., Nat. Chiaotung Univ., Hsinchu, Taiwan
authors.name: F.K. Hwang

details.abstract: An importance index measures the relative importance of a component in comparison to other components with respect to the system reliability. We survey many importance indices proposed in the literature, and some new ones of our own, to show how they relate. Our results can be used in two situations: 1) When components are functionally interchangeable, then more reliable units should go to the more important components. 2) When there is a fixed budget to improve the system reliability, the more important components should get first attention if everything else is equal.

context.text: The Birnbaum importance [1] was originally defined in the larger framework where component reliabilities, and component locations, are both considered.

references.title: On the importance of different components in a multicomponent system
references.text: P. R. Krishnaiah, "On the importance of different components in a multicomponent system" in Multivariate Analysis II, 1969, Academic.

context.text: Reference [2] proposed an importance index which is slightly weaker than the absoluteness index, but stronger than other indices proposed in the literature.

references.title: Optimal arrangement of components via pairwise rearrangements
references.text: P. J. Boland, F. Proschan, Y. L. Tong, "Optimal arrangement of components via pairwise rearrangements", Nav. Res. Logist. Quart., vol. 36, pp. 807-815, 1989.

context.text: Reference [3] called component \$i\$ to be more cut-important than component \$j\$ if the vector \$(b _{i1}, b _{i2},\ldots, b_{in})\$ is lexicographically larger than the vector \$(b _{j1}, b _{j2},\ldots, b_{jn})\$.
[3] also proved that Meng [8] proved that strictly more critical implies strictly more cut-important.
[3] also pointed out that for \$p \rightarrow 1\$, then \$i\$ more cut-important than \$j\$ dictates a more reliable unit goes to \$i\$ rather than \$j\$.

references.title: A complete importance ranking for components of binary coherent systems with extensions to multi-state systems
references.text: D. A. Butler, "A complete importance ranking for components of binary coherent systems with extensions to multi-state systems", Nav. Res. Logist. Quart., vol. 4, pp. 565-578, 1979.

context.text: Because the Birnbaum importance is very hard to compare, [4] proposed the half-line importance, which is much easier to handle mathematically, and also practical in applications.

references.title: Rare-event component importance for the consecutive-
references.text: H. W. Chang, F. K. Hwang, " Rare-event component importance for the consecutive- \$k\$ system ", Nav. Res. Logist. Quart., vol. 49, pp. 159-166, 2002.

context.text: Recently, [5] introduced the notion of rare-event importance, which is the counterpart of first-term importance, by comparing \$\left\vert {\mathtilde P_{i}} \right\vert\$ with \$\left\vert {\mathtilde P_{j}} \right\vert\$.

references.title: The structural birnbaum importance of consecutive-
references.text: H. W. Chang, R. J. Chen, F. K. Hwang, " The structural birnbaum importance of consecutive- \$k\$ systems ", J. Combinatorial Optimization, vol. 6, pp. 183-197, 2002.

links.abstract: A simple method is given for calculating a) reliability characteristics of repairable and nonrepairable systems, and b) the importance of the individual system components. Assumptions made include independent component failures and constant failure and repair rates for the components. The methods can easily be implemented in a computer program that would be inexpensive to execute and would always overpredict (usually very slightly) the system failure characteristics.

context.text: A specification of the \$n\$ component-states will be called an inoperative sample point if it causes a system inoperativeness. [11] and [6] proposed the VF importance of location \$i\$ as the probability that a random inoperative sample point contains a minimum cutset in \$\mathtilde C_{i}\$.

references.title: How to hand-calculate system reliability and safety characteristics
references.text: J. B. Fussell, "How to hand-calculate system reliability and safety characteristics", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-24, pp. 169-174, 1975.

context.text: We strengthen a result of [7] to prove.

references.title: A new index of component importance
references.text: F. K. Hwang, "A new index of component importance", Oper. Res. Lett., vol. 28, pp. 25-29, 2001.

context.text: Reference [8] considered “more important” in its strict sense and proved that “\$c\$-absolutely more important” implies more critical.

Reference [3] called component \$i\$ to be more cut-important than component \$j\$ if the vector \$(b _{i1}, b _{i2},\ldots, b_{in})\$ is lexicographically larger than the vector \$(b _{j1}, b _{j2},\ldots, b_{jn})\$. [3] also proved that Meng [8] proved that strictly more critical implies strictly more cut-important.

references.title: Comparing criticality of nodes via minimal cut (path) sets for coherent systems
references.text: F. C. Meng, "Comparing criticality of nodes via minimal cut (path) sets for coherent systems", Probabilities in Engineering and Information Sciences, vol. 8, pp. 79-87, 1994.

links.abstract: Various results concerning importance measures and rankings of system components are presented. The vectors (of component states) which appear useful in studying various component importance measures are decomposed. In particular, a new method to compute Birnbaum importance measures of components is introduced. For some systems and components the Vesely-Fussell importance measure might not be suitable; thus a new importance measure is proposed. By using the notion of component criticality introd...

context.text: [9] gave a quite complicated proof that “strictly more critical” implies “strictly more VF-important.” Ignoring strictness, then the result easily follows from the coupling property of comparing criticality.
[9] also defined a pathset version of VF-importance.

references.title: Comparing the importance of system components by some structural characteristics
references.text: F. C. Meng, "Comparing the importance of system components by some structural characteristics", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 45, pp. 59-65, 1996.

context.text: [10] introduced the notion of “first-term invariance” by comparing the number of minimum cutsets of two assignments.

references.title: Consecutive-2 systems on trees
references.text: M. Santha, Y. Zhang, "Consecutive-2 systems on trees", Probabilities in Engineering and Information Sciences, vol. 1, pp. 441-456, 1987.

context.text: [11] and [6] proposed the VF importance of location \$i\$ as the probability that a random inoperative sample point contains a minimum cutset in \$\mathtilde C_{i}\$.

references.title: A time dependent methodology for fault tree evaluation
references.text: W. E. Vesely, "A time dependent methodology for fault tree evaluation", Nuclear Engineering Designs, vol. 13, pp. 337-360, 1970.
